job_title: Graduate Researcher in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Intellectual Growth: As a graduate researcher, you have the opportunity to delve deep into a specific subject area, conducting in-depth research and contributing to the existing body of knowledge. This process stimulates intellectual growth and allows you to expand your expertise and understanding in your chosen field. Professional Development: Being a graduate researcher provides valuable professional development opportunities. You develop critical thinking skills, enhance your problem-solving abilities, and gain proficiency in research methodologies. Additionally, you may have the chance to present your work at conferences and publish your findings, which can boost your credibility and open doors for future career prospects. Mentorship and Networking: Graduate research often involves collaboration with experienced faculty members and researchers who can act as mentors. They can guide you in your research, offer advice, and share their knowledge and expertise. Furthermore, working in a research setting allows you to network with other researchers, professionals, and peers, fostering connections that can be beneficial for your future career. Personal Fulfillment: Engaging in meaningful research that aligns with your interests and passions can be personally fulfilling. It provides a sense of purpose and accomplishment as you contribute to the advancement of knowledge in your field. The opportunity to make discoveries, solve complex problems, and have a positive impact on society can be highly rewarding. Specialization and Expertise: As a graduate researcher, you have the chance to specialize in a specific area of study. By focusing on a particular research topic, you can become an expert in that field, which can lead to unique career opportunities, such as becoming a subject matter expert, consultant, or professor. Specialization enhances your marketability and distinguishes you in the job market.
cons: Long working hours: Graduate researchers often have demanding schedules and may need to work long hours, including evenings and weekends, to meet project deadlines or conduct experiments. This can lead to a lack of work-life balance and potential burnout. Uncertain funding: Many graduate researchers rely on funding from grants or scholarships, which can be unpredictable or limited in duration. The uncertainty of securing funding for ongoing research can create financial instability and stress. High pressure and competition: Graduate research can be highly competitive, with the pressure to produce publishable results and stand out in the academic community. This can lead to a stressful work environment and feelings of imposter syndrome or self-doubt. Limited income and benefits: Compared to industry positions, graduate researchers often receive modest stipends or salaries. They may also have limited access to benefits such as health insurance, retirement plans, or paid time off, which can impact their financial well-being. Isolation and limited social interaction: Graduate researchers often spend significant amounts of time working independently or in small research groups. This can result in a sense of isolation and limited opportunities for social interaction, which may affect their well-being and mental health.

job_title: Senior Lecturer in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: None at all. No value or support for staff
cons: Don’t come to northumbria if you wish to be research active. Only a few staff succeed and the university is blacklisted with many major funders. You will be promised that you will have an attenuated teaching load and guaranteed research time - to then be insidiously and narcissistically given more and more teaching and admin roles and pulled away from research. If you end up at northumbria in research - you are kissing goodbye to excelling in research. Staff are promoted to AP who have never secured external funding or can prove an independent track record but are yes people and don’t complain. Some profs have not published or secured funding in over 5 years - yet still call the shots on the fate of younger academics. If you value yourself as a scientist and researcher - don’t come here.

review_title: Disappointing experience and messy work environment
job_title: Lecturer in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
Nice colleagues at lower scales.
Newcastle is a good city to live.
cons:
Only care about students not academic staff
Bullying senior staff 
Very poor communication at every level
Very poor induction
HR, IT, Safety, Resource/Finance teams make processes more complicated
They do not give you basics about how to get your IT equipment, they do not contact you to inform you that they leave IT equipmets in your office, I have to go each time and track the progress. 
Totally messy at every level. 
Management people do not understand what is happening below them. 
Confusing structures to get access to research labs and facilities. They make simple things very complicated. non standard and stressful process 
Some senior lecturers do not know the basis of teaching! no idea how these people got the job! Some senior academic staff do not how to communicate with their module teams, and make your life like a hell. If you complain, they'll bully you because you are at the lower ranking! Management people ignore these bullying. 
I got serious mental health issues. 
EDI leaders only focus on women in science stuff... and ignore bullying 
incompetent support staff. You have to keep contacting them and ask and ask and ask... tidious... they do not keep you updated when things are done.
IT has made access to basic softwares so complicated. Some of these essential softwares must be available from Software Centre! 
Too many international students, bringing many weak students to the university, and feeding them with a first-class degree. Some international students have very poor English writing skills.
Very low start salary for Lecturer
University only focus on refurbishment for students, best desks, chairs, IT equipments are for them. Staff get the worst.
Promotion are not competitive. People become senior lecturer without getting any funds above 100,000 pounds and having a successful PhD student. Only FHEA and higher starting salary make it easy for promotion!

job_title: Senior Lecturer in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: There is nothing to be positive about. Even the buildings are ugly, dysfunctional and most should be demolished but asbestos prevents that.
cons: Salary pathetic, abysmal management, nonsensical bureaucracy, ineffective HR, students lazy and thick, modules and marking dumbed down, most people there would stab you in the back to get on themselves, favouritism rife, pathetic feminist domination, spineless staff who will not stand up for themselves, barely sentient VC who is just out for himself, ageism rife, bullying, complaints ignored, common sense ignored, have to pay to park car, timetabling incompetent, IT pathetic, technicians largely incompetent, too many thick foreign students, too much focus on students supposedly unless they ask for something which management don't want to do, no discussions with staff before decisions taken, costing is infantile, too much pressure to bring in research funding to detriment of serious research, petty and vindictive 'management', VC sense of superiority (unjustified), just a money-making machine for senior management, offices tiny, complete lack of respect for academic staff, most canteens abysmal, don't like you taking holidays, want you to work 12 months a year. This is not a proper 'university'. 'Yes men' on board of governors who are only there to agree massive and unjustified pay rises to VC etc. Working there made me ill, to be honest. If I could give zero stars for everything then I would.

job_title: International Recruitment Coordinator in Newcastle, England
pros:
Incredible opportunity to travel the world. Ideal for anyone who enjoys meeting and talking to new people - prospective students, other recruiters, agents, partner unis etc. 
Organised recruitment tours can be a lot of fun, spending a week travelling around a country doing recruitment fairs in the day and going for dinner or exploring each city at night.
A lot of autonomy to plan recruitment strategies in your markets and cover trips in other markets to gain experience. Managers keen to share their knowledge and tips so you learn fast. Good progression routes. Northumbria pays above the sector average.
cons:
Travel takes its toll. Expect delayed flights, 6hr buses and trying to look professional while living out of a suitcase. 
Can be difficult to remain enthusiastic when promoting a mid-ranking university and (in my opinion) extortionate tuition fees, especially when the UK is becoming less attractive compared to more welcoming or affordable countries. 
Can be boring between recruitment trips as there's not much to do in the office and some colleagues can be resentful. 
Frequent restructures can be stressful, even if your job is safe. 
I don't think any of these problems are unique to Northumbria though - it's a great place to do this job.

review_title: Northumbria Students Union Bar Staff Review
job_title: Bar Staff in Newcastle, England
pros:
Super relaxed for the most part in terms of the culture behind the bar, however it can get a bit stressful if there as the queue can get very large. After time youll learn that you can only serve a small number of people at a time and the pressure will fade away. 

I was a baaaad employee the first few weeks and kept being late and missing shifts. I was not fired and they were super nice about it.
cons: Its hard to think of them. I would maybe say getting shifts is a pain, especially at first when everyone is desperate for them. Sometimes working at night too, so you may have to skip a big night out, especially over freshers. However as the year gets on it is normally easy enough to swap shifts.

review_title: Worked for the Uni for 12 months

review_title: Lovely staff,  organisation,  systems and processes need improvement
job_title: Lecturer in Newcastle, England
pros: Very flexible working.  Team and colleagues are supportive and cooperative. Frequent opportunity to develop ideas and work autonomously toward individual goals
cons:
Workload assessment is not equitable or reflective of staff productivity. Cut backs and reorganisation mean systems and processes are not joined up, are hugely frustrating and time wasting to use. Admin tasks take up significant time which could be used to better effect. 
Organisational culture is one which pressures high achieving staff to perform but avoids performance management of under performing staff. Whilst staff consultation happens, there is little in the way of really addressing the significant concerns of staff groups and being responsive to this

review_title: Now a shadow of its former self under the current management.
job_title: IT Developer in Newcastle, England
pros: Good pension, generous leave and flexi time.
cons:
I used to love working in IT Systems at Northumbria, no more sadly. Under the current management regime, the old 'can-do' culture has been replaced by a culture of fear and intimidation.
Wages have been cut and entire pay grades abolished, good skilled staff with a wealth of skills and experience are being ignored and sidelined in favour of yes-men and brown-nosers, projects that could have been developed in-house have been outsourced at great expense, enterprise systems replaced by inadequate open source software, experienced managers forced out and replaced by clueless box-tickers...
Staff speaking out have been threatened with dismissal and legal action. 
Not a nice place to work any more unfortunately.

job_title: Professional Support in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Not many - maybe the city centre location if you can use public transport otherwise parking charges have recently be massively increased. But that's about it.
cons:
Arrogant Management. This Uni is leading the charge towards privatisation and polarisation.
Big salaries and pay rises for those at the top (often imported from the wonderful private sector) and stagnant salaries and extra pressure for those at the bottom. Those who are grade 5 and below may no longer join the LGPS instead there's a defined contribution scheme. In most support areas there are not enough people to get the work done properly.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Long established reputation is still worth something – the 'brand' name. Attractive city to work and study is popular with many students. Buildings have seen major improvements in quality and structure.
cons: Dreadful management with a 'one-size-fits-all approach'. Ever ongoing re-structuring and constant change. Continuing centralisation, out sourcing and tick-boxing. Staff increasingly left feeling demoralised, belittled and worthless by a self-important management that seems incapable of listening and prefers the stick to the carrot. As a people business, there is little interest in staff happiness and satisfaction.

review_title: Used to be great but is being slowly eroded by senior management and an inept Vice Chancellor

job_title: Research Assistant in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Good facilities for research, some good staff around to collaborate. Nice working space with good connection for the subburbs and local ammenities.
cons: The university management is poor, very hard to go through with the paper work, even harder to get anythibg organised. Lack of care for common wealth is the worst, with some employees working against and not with progress. Lack of initiatives and money to apply for grands, and only local-insignificant projects are supported.

job_title: PhD Student in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: This university is a  new university in England with very beautiful campus and very advanced equipment. Newcastle is a really nice city for students to study and live.
cons: The ranking of this university is not very high due to it is a new university. Therefore, the research funding maybe not very much compared to some old good universities.

job_title: PhD Student in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: They provide excellent facilities for personal development. They have one of the best libraries ever and also the careers advice section is brilliant. Very friendly environment, I'd advise you to get involved with one of the student societies, there are lots to choose from. The sports centre is super awesome and convenient as well
cons: While the university is well known for fields such as business, law and sports; it is not well known for science. So if you enter science like me, do not expect too much prestige when you walk out

job_title: Management Accountant/Finance Business Partner in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Good salary, good facilities, good location, professional support (non academics) staff are usually brilliant, Academic staff are entertaining, good career progression and training prospects.
cons:
I hear car parking sucks in the City Centre (you could always cycle and use the excellent facilities on hand).

Academics run the university, unfortunately in this climate it needs to be run as a business therefore a lot of poor decision making happens at the top.

Very top heavy management which are frankly not needed.

job_title: Support in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Used to be good but cuts are eroding that every day.
cons:
The massive cuts in staff have left people struggling to cope. There's no job security in support areas. Management just load more work onto less people. The wage savings from all of the staff redundancies are being used to build or acquire new buildings but support staff are on the edge.
Management seem to think this is the way it should be and dismiss concerns.

job_title: Senior Lecturer in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
Good work and life balance
Great autonomy
Great support for early career researchers
Great training programs
Very good work culture
cons:
Too many changes to structure.
No proper vision and the changes do not make it easy to stick to one plan.
More attention and concern for staff who are always missing from work place and almost no attention for staff who work hard to cover for missing staff.
HR policies are hilarious. Individuals can choose not to come to work without informing anyone. No disciplinary action is taking against such individuals.

job_title: Manager in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Fantastic team of colleagues. Great pay and benefits including pension scheme, onsite nursery, discounted travel and local company discounts. The university also has flexible working arrangements and good training and development opportunities.
cons: The university has undergone a period of change in the last few years which whilst needed has unsettled some teams and colleagues. The University has involved colleagues in development of future plans which has been really useful and seem to be listening to the feedback from the staff survey.

review_title: I taught there for over ten years as a Programme Leader.
job_title: Senior Lecturer in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Excellent, dedicated,colleagues who provided first class tuition and support in the face of many handicaps.
cons:
Appalling management that resorted to bullying academic staff.  This has led to the loss of many experienced academic and support staff.  

Senior and middle management would make bad decisions, refuse to listen to feedback from academic and technical staff, and then blame them when things went wrong.  Bad policies would be introduced with a fanfare and then quietly dropped when they failed.  Usually staff would not be informed that these policies had been dropped and would continue trying to implement the unworkable long after their demise.  

There was a complete lack of priorities, every management idea was urgent and top priority.  

Towards the end of my time there I found that overseas students with poor English language skills were being recruited which meant I had to pair them with another student who shared their language but had better English so that they could translate for them,  This was very unfair to them both.  I found that staff had to fight to maintain academic standards as middle management seemed intent on 'dumbing down' the curricula.

job_title: Bar Staff in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
Permanent shifts offering certain hours each week
A lot of extra shift to pick up if needed
cons:
Not very thorough training in the beginning
No discounts on drinks/food whatsoever

job_title: Academic in Newcastle, England
pros: Flexible working environment (although this is very dependent on manager and role)
cons: Abysmal management. No appreciation of staff. Lost focus on core business i.e. educating students. Driven by checkboxes and targets. Lacks humanity in the work place.

review_title: The Unhappiest most self destructive place I have ever seen. An Awful Place to Work!
job_title: Business Manager in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
- Coffee shop is nice
- Just opened a subway in cafe. 
- Some (very few) genuinely amazing people.
cons:
- Delusional Executive Board with no clue how to create a motivational work culture. 

- Unrealistic corporate strategy based on pipe dreams instead of fact/ plausibility.

- Non existent performance management, leading to organisation wide deliberete incompetence, laziness and lack of effort. Very frustrating for those who wish to succeed. 

- HR department look after thier own and do not provide any support to rest of organisation. 

Organisational culture of punishing those who think outside the box, use initiative or even try. Instead keeping quiet and being agreeable is rewarded. This is reflected in promotions across organisation which has led to many line managers with 0 managerial/ leadership ability running departments/ teams into the ground. (Peter's Principle is rife). 

- Non existent leadership development which further compounds above issue. 

- Non existent career development opportunities unless you have friends in the interview.

- Organisational culture of "do as I say and not as I do" in which leaders/ organisational role models consistently break their own rules whilst penalising those around them who do the same. 

- Inter Faculty agression, unhealthy competitition and deliberate disruption makes it impossible to do anything properly. 

- PFNA was revolutionary in principle, but has been implemented so poorly it has actually been detrimental to the organisation. 

- Organisational restructure was based on pie in the sky ideas of what should be done and not on business logic or fact. Now the entire organisation is understaffed, underperforming and massively behind schedule on day to day workloads.

- Mass dissention and unhappieness amongst staff. Which is dismissed by executive leadership who hope to ignore the real issues. 

- Many Lecturers across organisation expect silver spoon moddy coddling and treat operational staff in a very disraspectful way. 

- Culture promotes disrespect to students and as though they are lesser in value than the customers anywhere else.

review_title: Versatile work related assignments. Fast paced environment.
job_title: Project Manager in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Great atmosphere. Interesting project work with a lot of variety. Good salary package compared with the industry average.
cons: Limited resources and cut to the bone staffing on the mid-management and lower management level. A lengthy process of financial and procurement approvals. Paper-based business management processes do not match the external modern university image.

job_title: Associate Lecturer in Newcastle, England
pros: - positive environment, nice students, the colleague I work with appears to be helpful and friendly
cons: I haven't come across any downsides of working here yet as I've only been here for a short while.

job_title: Senior Lecturer in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Flexible hours, good pay and holidays. Good colleagues. Generally a nice environment to work in. Always trying to get better.
cons: Forever changing. Little trust in staff. Too much micro management from above. Too much red-tape. Often poor communication and inclusion of the right people.

job_title: Lecturer in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: University and faculty management passion and support for research.
cons:
Too much admin/teaching requirements
Departmental management not keen on research
Lack of transparency at the departmental management level

job_title: Professional Support in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: I have worked at the University for over 5 years and I have had many opportunities to undertake training and development activities to progress my career.  The campus environment is fantastic and there are lots of great facilities including an excellent sport centre.
cons: There is lots to do and sometimes we need to prioritise better.

job_title: Student Ambassador in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: I am involved in representing my university, it allows me to gain a large amount of communication skills and practice presentation skills. the pay is its 7.82 an hour which pretty good for the role which we perform
cons: sometimes we have to stand outside in the cold, when we weren't expecting it

job_title: Senior Lecturer in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
Good work-life balance.
Nice people.
Students are generally good.
Facilities are excellent.
Investment in buildings.
cons:
Management have no idea what is actually going on.
Promotion on the basis of brown-nosing rather than ability.
Admin heavy.

job_title: Senior Lecturer in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: What an excellent experience working with Social Work faculty at Northumbria. The department was dedicated, professional and really supportive of an American learning UK academics. I felt this experience added to my teaching tenfold.
cons: The only cons were in administrative support but the management was working on it.

job_title: Administrative in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Flexi time and pay is comparably generous
cons: Constantly changing environment meant staff were always on edge, management had no change management abilities whatsoever, very few progression opportunities.

review_title: Good if you are happy to trundle on bottom rung. Brown nosing required to progress.
job_title: Senior Lecturer in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Nice colleagues on bottom rung. Good coffee.
cons: To progress you need to brown nose or be married to management.

job_title: Analyst in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Leave OK. Central city location.
cons: Everything else. All done on the cheap. Senior management have a like it or lump it attitude towards staff.

review_title: Colleagues great, management not so much
job_title: Research Scientist in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Fantastic can-do colleagues offer help to each other. Great facilities and city centre location
cons: Everything managed through (sometimes poor quality) digital systems. Mistrustful managers try to force ‘One University’ thinking which really means little local autonomy

review_title: Generally good working conditions but unworkable processes grind you down.
job_title: Senior Lecturer in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Flexibility and autonomous working. Superb colleagues.
cons: Procedures that are in fact inefficient when meant to be to improve efficiency. Employees are not valued. Limited prospects for career development.

review_title: Not for those with independent thought
job_title: IT Worker in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
Main campus has city centre location, leave entitlement OK, not much else.
Fellow workers are often great but struggling with incompetent management.
cons: You need to be a toady to get on. Management hate being contradicted or even questioned, yet they are mostly pretty useless, especially in IT.

job_title: Graduate Trainee in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Flexible hours (to a point), lots of opportunities to move within teams and learn new things. Uni has a clear vision for the future
cons: Pace of change is slower than average. Some staff are too comfortable in their jobs and a lot of bureaucracy

job_title: PhD Candidate in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Pleasant and friendly environment, quite fully equipped laboratories to grow your research
cons: The University is located near the city centre and thus the space you get to work (both in the lab and in the PhD office) is limited.

job_title: IT
pros: Location in Central Newcastle upon Tyne
cons:
Job Insecurity.
The programme of job cuts is placing all support services on a knife-edge.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Excellent experience, great people. Provides learning to create a well rounded security officer, dealing with issues that may put you out of your comfort, however this creates personal growth.
cons: Shift changes making home, work life balance a challenge.

job_title: Student Representative in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Excellent opportunity to earn some money. Very flexible hours and great experience for when you graduate.
cons: Minimum wage pay and you need to jump at other student rep opportunities if you want to earn more money.

job_title: PhD Student in Newcastle, England
pros: Nice relaxed atmosphere to work, very friendly and supportive staff. Newcastle is a great city.
cons: Too much focus on sports and nutrition affects research in life sciences sector.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
Flexible, good training, nice offices, friendly co
Workers, good rates of pay, central location, flexi time, good work experience, good work structure, self managed teams
cons: Restructures, no cash point at coach lane campus.

job_title: Lecturer in Newcastle, England
pros: Good place for early career lecturers.
cons: Too much teaching focused. Some times 5 days a week

review_title: Great students and staff. Abysmal leadership
